title: Acroloxidae
text:
Acroloxidae, commonly known as river limpets, are a <a href="Taxonomy%20%28biology%29">taxonomic</a> family of very small, <a href="freshwater%20snail">freshwater snail</a>s, <a href="Aquatic%20animal">aquatic</a> <a href="pulmonate">pulmonate</a> <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> limpet-like <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a>s with a simple flattened conical <a href="gastropod%20shell">shell</a> in the clade <a href="Hygrophila%20%28Gastropoda%29">Hygrophila</a>.
Acroloxidae is the only family within the superfamily Acroloxoidea (according to the <a href="Taxonomy%20of%20the%20Gastropoda%20%28Bouchet%20%26amp%3B%20Rocroi%2C%202005%29">taxonomy of the Gastropoda by Bouchet & Rocroi, 2005</a>).
Distribution.
Worldwide.
Anatomy.
Pulmones are reduced. Sexual cavity and <a href="Respiratory%20system%20of%20gastropods">accessory gills</a> are on the right side.

Genera within the family Acroloxidae include:
